title: To Bonnie From Delaney 1970
description:
Discovered yesterday that this classic had disappeared from the Net in FLAC/LOSSLESS format.  I simply couldn't abide that, so with the help of the Oldish Psych and Prog Blog, I converted and uploaded this FLAC version to keep the music ALIVE! Enjoy!

Delaney and Bonnie - From Bonnie To Delaney (1970) 

ATCO Records - AMCY-2764 - CD - Japan

Track List -- 
1) Hard Luck and Troubles	
2) God Knows I Love You
3) Lay Down My Burden
4) Medley: Come on in My Kitchen/Mama, He Treats Your Daughter Mean/Going	Down The Road Feeling Bad
5) The Love of My Man 
6) They Call It Rock & Roll Music
7) Soul Shake 
8) Miss Ann
9) Alone Together
10) Living on the Open Road
11) Let Me Be Your Man
12) Free the People 

Review From Allmusic.com -- 

Delaney and BonnieÃ‚Â hit their pop-soul prime on this, their first Atlantic Records album. Buoyed by their acclaim from their first Elektra album, as well as their association withÃ‚Â Eric Clapton, the group switched record labels and recorded this, probably their most definitive album. Backed by an awesome cast of musicians which includedÃ‚Â Jim GordonÃ‚Â (drums),Kenny GradneyÃ‚Â (bass -- later ofÃ‚Â Little Feat), and many others, this record shows why anyone connected with the band became a tambourine-shaking convert to soul-based rhythm & blues rock. Some great vocal performances byÃ‚Â Bonnie Bramlett, especially the low-down "The Love of My Man," show why she was put in the same league asÃ‚Â Janis Joplin. One of the more definitive albums of the period.
